titles.title: Model for Five Disks: One Empty

makers.displaydate: 1898–1976; born Lawnton, PA; died New York, NY; active Paris, France, and Roxbury, CT
makers.displaymaker: Alexander Calder, 1898–1976; born Lawnton, PA; died New York, NY; active Paris, France, and Roxbury, CT

texts.textentryhtml: Calder is best known for his kinetic sculptures, or mobiles; his stationary sculptures, such as Five Disks: One Empty—for which this work is a model—are known as stabiles. This term was coined by his fellow artist and friend Hans Arp, who wanted to capture the sensation of  momentum and lightness he saw in the stationary sculptures. Princeton graduate and Museum of Modern Art curator Alfred Barr invited Calder to make the large-scale work for the Princeton campus. The sculpture was originally painted orange to honor Princeton’s colors, but the artist requested that it be repainted black after observing it from atop the thirteen-story-tall Fine Hall tower, across from which the sculpture sits.

bibliography.boilertext: Allen Rosenbaum and Francis F. Jones, Selections from The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: The Art Museum, Princeton University, 1986)
bibliography.citation: Allen Rosenbaum and Francis F. Jones, Selections from The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: The Art Museum, Princeton University, 1986), p. 296 (illus.)
